title: 105_hr846
content:
Section 1 introduces a new constructive sales treatment for appreciated financial positions under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. If there is a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position, the taxpayer must recognize gain as if the position were sold for its fair market value on the date of the sale. Any gain must be included in the taxable year of the sale, and adjustments will be made for any subsequent realized gains or losses related to the position. The term 'appreciated financial position' refers to any stock, debt instrument, or partnership interest that would result in a gain if sold. When there is a constructive sale of such a position, the taxpayer must recognize gain as if the position were sold at its fair market value on the sale date. Adjustments will be made for any subsequent realized gains or losses related to the position. The term 'position' refers to an interest such as a futures contract, short sale, or option. A taxpayer is considered to have made a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position if they engage in certain transactions like a short sale of the same property. The term 'position' refers to an interest such as a futures contract, short sale, or option. A taxpayer is considered to have made a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position if they engage in certain transactions like a short sale of the same or substantially identical property, entering into an offsetting notional principal contract, or acquiring the same or substantially identical property. The term 'constructive sale' includes acquiring the same or substantially identical property, or entering into transactions with similar effects. Transactions marked to market are exempt from this definition. The term 'constructive sale' excludes sales of nonpublicly traded property within 1 year of contract entry and transactions closed by year end, disregarding appreciated financial positions. In applying the constructive sale rules, any appreciated financial position sold or disposed of during the taxable year is disregarded, as well as any other transaction treated as a constructive sale if closed before the end of the taxable year. In applying the constructive sale rules, any appreciated financial position sold or disposed of during the taxable year is disregarded, as well as any other transaction treated as a constructive sale if closed before the end of the taxable year. A person is related to another person with respect to a transaction if the relationship is described in section 267 or 707(b). For purposes of this section, a person is related to another person in a transaction if the relationship is described in section 267 or 707(b). Positions in interest rates are treated as substantially identical to debt instruments for certain purposes. The term 'forward contract' includes fully or partially prepaid contracts. "(d) Other Definitions: 
1) Forward contract includes fully or partially prepaid contracts.
2) Offsetting notional principal contract involves paying the investment yield on a property in exchange for reimbursement for any decline in value and other considerations.
(e) Special Rules: 
1) Treatment of subsequent sale of a position deemed sold." The special rules address the subsequent sale of a position that was deemed sold due to a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position. If the position is later sold or disposed of while the initial transaction is still open, it is considered for determining further constructive sales. For the purpose of determining constructive sales of appreciated financial positions, a taxpayer is treated as entering into a transaction immediately after a sale or disposition. Trust interests actively traded are treated as stock. If a portion of property is constructively sold, special rules apply for multiple positions. The taxpayer is treated as entering into a transaction immediately after a sale or disposition for determining constructive sales of appreciated financial positions. Trust interests actively traded are treated as stock. Special rules apply for multiple positions in property deemed sold. Regulations will be prescribed by the Secretary to carry out the purposes of this section. Securities traders may elect mark to market. Securities traders engaged in active trading may elect mark to market accounting method for dealers in securities. This allows them to be treated as dealers for tax purposes. Securities traders engaged in active trading may elect mark to market accounting method to be treated as dealers in securities for tax purposes. Securities held in connection with the trade or business are not considered held for investment. The election can be made without the Secretary's consent and applies to the year made and subsequent years unless revoked with consent. A clerical amendment is made to the table of sections for part IV of subchapter P of chapter 1 of the Code. Sec. 1259 addresses the constructive sales treatment for appreciated financial positions, with specific effective date provisions for the amendments made by this section. The enactment of this Act requires the taxpayer to own the appreciated financial position subject to the constructive sale 30 days after the enactment date. Section 1259 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 applies as if the constructive sale occurred 30 days after the enactment date. The special rule applies if a decedent dies after the enactment of the Act and there was a constructive sale of an appreciated financial position before that date. The sale of a position open with respect to the decedent or any related person, where gain has not been recognized under section 1259 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, will be treated as property constituting rights to receive income in respect of a decedent under section 691 of the Code. Securities traders can elect to be treated as dealers. The amendment allows securities traders to elect to be treated as dealers for taxable years beginning after the enactment of the Act. Taxpayers can spread adjustments over 5 years if they change their accounting method under section 475(d)(4) of the Internal Revenue Code. The net amount of adjustments required under section 481 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 shall be spread ratably over a 5-year period for taxpayers changing their accounting method. SEC. 2. LIMITATION ON EXCEPTION FOR INVESTMENT COMPANIES UNDER SECTION 351. Amends section 351(e) of the Internal Revenue Code to include all stock and securities in determining if a company is an investment company. Effective for transfers after the enactment date in taxable years ending after that date.
